poll_list.title: Ratification Poll for Modify the Collateral Application Form (MIP6c3-SP2) - April 11, 2022

discourse_list.title: MIP6c3-SP2: Modify the collateral application form

content.content: MIP6c3-SP2: Modify the collateral application form  Preamble MIP6c3-SP: 2 Title: Subproposal for changing the collateral application form Author(s): @lollike, @monkey.irish Contributors:  Tags: mip-amendment Status: Accepted Date Proposed: 2022-03-09 Date Ratified: 2022-04-25 Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip6c3-sp2-modify-the-collateral-application-form/13787 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmTGxRjL   Specification  Motivation Since the inception of MIP6, MakerDAO and Core Units involved in collateral onboarding have gained a lot of insights from onboarding new collateral types into the Maker Protocol. These insights allow us to better understand what collateral types are desirable for MakerDAO from a risk, cost and revenue perspective. Furthermore, analyzing the past work has allowed us to more precisely estimate the amount of work and cost of onboarding and continuously maintain collateral types in the Maker Protocol. In addition, CES has analyzed previous domain team assessments and have solicited general input from said domain teams to understand what data is necessary for them to make an informed assessment. The fact that the MakerDAO community has greenlit many assets, of which the majority according to Core Units involved in the collateral onboarding process is not fit for onboarding is a symptom of lack of relevant information to make an informed decision. The conclusion of this analysis by CES and Collateral Management Onchain (CMON) Stakeholders is that the current application template does not contain all necessary information for Core Units or MakerDAO to make an initial informed decision whether or not a collateral type should be greenlit. This leads to Core Units and the general MakerDAO community having to spend time searching for information, rather than just verifying the correctness of data presented upfront. The goal is therefore to amend the collateral application template to contain relevant questions that allow Core Units and the MakerDAO community to more easily make an informed opinion on whether or not a collateral type is fit to be greenlit to be onboarded into the Maker Protocol. Comparing applications based on the new application template with the (soon to come) recommended metrics should therefore give the MakerDAO community a much better framework for assessing collateral applications.  List of Changes to Application Questions The template has been rearranged and grouped into new sections. Therefore the entire new collateral template, containing both existing and new questions is proposed below. Background Information   Who is the interested party for this collateral application?   Provide a brief high-level overview of the project, with a focus on the applying collateral token.   How long has the project been live in production?   Provide a brief history of the project.   Link the whitepaper, documentation portals, and source code for the system(s) that interact with the proposed collateral, and all relevant Ethereum addresses. If the system is complex, schematic(s) are especially appreciated.   Asset Information   What type of asset is it? (e.g. store of value, currency, commodity, capital asset, governance token etc.)   How is the asset used and does it give any rights to holders? (e.g. financial claims, dividends, governance rights)   What is the market cap for the asset?   Where does exchange for the asset occur? 9.a  Provide exchange data on market liquidity, volume and order book depth.   Is the asset settled on chain (trustless) or off chain (trusted)?   If offchain (trusted) settlement: describe what are the involved entities, process and estimated time.   List any possible oracle data sources for the proposed collateral type.   List any parties interested in taking part in liquidations for the proposed collateral type.   Business Questions   What is/are the expected use case(s) of the Dai generated by the vault?   What is the amount of Dai expected to be generated against the collateral and what is the timeline? Is there a commitment on a minimum amount of Dai to be generated?   What are the strategic benefits for MakerDAO in onboarding the collateral?   Legal Questions   What are the legal risks associated with the tokens?   (Optional) Does one organization bear legal responsibility for the collateral? What jurisdiction does that organization reside in?   (Optional) Has your project obtained any legal opinions or memoranda regarding the regulatory standing of the token or an explanation of the same from the perspective of any jurisdiction? If so, those materials should be provided for community review.   (Optional) Describe whether there are any regulatory registrations for the token and provide related documentation (including an explanation of any past or existing interactions with any regulatory authorities, regardless of jurisdiction), if applicable.   Is issuance of the asset decentralized (trustless) or centralized (trusted)? 20.a  If centralized/trusted: by which legal entity, type of entity and jurisdiction?   Technical Questions   Link any available audits of the project. Both procedural and smart contract focused audits.   Has the token (and/or supporting protocol) been formally verified?   Does the asset follow a token standard? (E.g. ERC20, ERC721, ERC1400)   Is the asset, or asset balances, controlled by a central actor, or group of actors (e.g. through a multisig, or DAO)?   Does the token have whitelist or blacklist functions? If so, what is the process for utilization and what stakeholders are involved?   Can the token implementation be upgraded/changed? If so, what is the process and what stakeholders are involved?   Does the token contain rebasing logic?
content.GPT-summary: The post proposes a modification to the collateral application form for MakerDAO. The proposal explains the motivation behind the change and lists the new questions that will be added to the application form. The post also provides background information, asset information, business questions, legal questions, and technical questions that will be included in the new application form. The post does not advertise the proposal, nor does it ask for collaboration or feedback.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: In addition to the proposed changes to the collateral application form, a set of guidelines will be provided separately at a later date that should help inform the MakerDAO community and collateral applicants on recommended minimum metrics for collateral onboarding.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: @blimpa Please move this into RFC. Thanks!

monkey.irish:  Does the asset follow any existing token standards? (E.g is it ERC20? Does it have 18 decimals?)   Good stuff—just one suggestion. Would it be better to rephrase this question more simplistic to “what existing token standard does the asset follow?” Since some popular platforms/protocols are using ERC 721/1155 standards. Also, maybe throw in a question of the applicants governance multisig standards? Just TOL

content.content: @collateral-core-unit @GovAlpha-Core-Unit Question for y’all? Are there any plans to look at MIP21 and MIP22 with regards to the onboarding process? Does MIP 21 and/or MIP22 allow applicants to onboard with a trust structure that is reviewed by their counsel and not necessarily a legal review that is taking into consideration the benefit of MakerDAO? In other words, how are MKR token owners protected from a self-contained MIP application being onboarded without legal review from MakerDAO’s side? Also, With regards to the possible precedent a self-contain onboarding MIP application sends to the masses—What’s stopping the next 150,000 Asset Originators  from applying via the Forum with self-contained MIP21 and MIP22 in an attempt to onboard? What role does GovAlpha play in governing the possibility of such? How is CES thinking about the onboarding process via MIP21 and MIP22?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal

content.content: flipflopflapdelegate:  Does MIP 21 and/or MIP22 allow applicants to onboard with a trust structure that is reviewed by their counsel and not necessarily a legal review that is taking into consideration the benefit of MakerDAO?   MIP21 and MIP22 describe structures, but they don’t describe processes. They don’t allow anyone to do anything that they couldn’t have with the top-level MIPs process.     flipflopflapdelegate:  In other words, how are MKR token owners protected from a self-contained MIP application being onboarded without legal review from MakerDAO’s side?   They are protected by their ability to vote down such proposals, either directly or through their delegates.     flipflopflapdelegate:  Also, With regards to the possible precedent a self-contain onboarding MIP application sends to the masses—What’s stopping the next 150,000 Asset Originators from applying via the Forum with self-contained MIP21 and MIP22 in an attempt to onboard?   MKR Holders and their delegates are preventing them from doing that through the voting process.     flipflopflapdelegate:  What role does GovAlpha play in governing the possibility of such?   Our relevant role in this instance is to enforce the governance processes agreed upon by Maker Governance. We can’t enforce processes that don’t exist. If Governance wants they can ratify a MIP that requires all RWA onboarding to come with an independent legal assessment, as judged by the RWA Core Unit (or some other entity capable of verifying such legal assessments). If such a MIP was ratified, GovAlpha could prevent MIPs that did not meet those requirements from entering the monthly governance process.

content.content: Hey! Moving way too fast these days and missed this. Yes, great suggestions. cc: @lollike

flipflopflapdelegate:  Are there any plans to look at MIP21 and MIP22 with regards to the onboarding process?   I agree with Long. There is a different between the collateral onboarding process (COB) and collateral technology. I’m not sure how clear this is in the community. For example, we have lots of collateral technology (some of this is from Frank’s post)  Regular collateral onboarding, ERC-20 GUNI type abstraction method CropJoin type abstraction method D3M method Institutional vaults PSM MIP21 MIP22 More coming…  In a MIP proposal, the proposer will need to list the technical implementation and gain a commitment from the Core Unit(s) doing the actual work. When using a MIP6, those commitments are covered by the Domain Teams. The big question for onboarding is, what are the relative priorities of the greenlit collateral? That’s what determines the order of collateral being onboarded. We are working to make this much clearer to the community.     flipflopflapdelegate:  What’s stopping the next 150,000 Asset Originators from applying via the Forum with self-contained MIP21 and MIP22 in an attempt to onboard?   This is a very good question. Today, we have a COB that starts with a MIP6. It’s not perfect and we are revising it. Each MIP proposer has the ability to list the collateral technology they would like to use. We have stakeholder alignment on what role each Domain Team will play in the COB. MIPs outside of this process are a question for me and currently, I do not have an answer for them. When MIPs are proposed that do not follow the COB, we reinvent the wheel vs. fixing it. The vision of the CES mandate is to operationalize collateral management within the Maker Protocol allowing anyone to onboard collateral while ensuring the stability and security of the ecosystem. I’m open to considering a new process to operationalize COB outside of the current process to support the ongoing needs of the protocol and community. ATM, I’m unsure what this would look and variability could lead to many one off solutions and negate the benefits of any such onboardings. Let us know if you have ideas.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: flipflopflapdelegate:  What’s stopping the next 150,000 Asset Originators from applying via the Forum with self-contained MIP21 and MIP22 in an attempt to onboard?   MIP21 and MIP22, the way I understand them, are just technical MIPs, they don’t - and cannot - enforce any meatspace agreements which is where most of the flesh currently is when onboarding RWAs. A project can totally describe a very good MIP21 and MIP22 integration (and such a situation, depending on how it is presented, is not discouraged at all), but such integration needs to reflect a set of legal agreements in the real world. These agreements need to be reviewed by RWF CU, and changes on the agreements might need to be reflected in the code base on the MIP21/22 integrations proposed, hence an Arranger cannot just deliver a MIP21/22 into the forum and call it the day. Governance could still vote it and execute a spell on such proposed integration, but without the meatspace agreements in place we would just be taking risks we are not aware of, and when things go sideways there might no be enough clarity in recourse actions at all, hence we would be rekt completely.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Reminder that this proposal will enter its Frozen Period in one week, on March 31, 2022. Last day for modifications is March 30, 2022. Substantive modifications beyond that date will render the proposal ineligible for the upcoming Governance Cycle / reset its Frozen Period, as the case may be. If you have any questions, please let me know!

content.content: monkey.irish:  Please note, the questions in the application template applying to RWA collateral onboarding applications will remain unchanged. For clarity, the RWA MIP6 applications would include the proposed application questions in this MIP in addition to the existing RWA questions currently in the application template.   I added: For clarity, the RWA MIP6 applications would include the proposed application questions in this MIP in addition to the existing RWA questions currently in the application template. I think this is implied although I wanted to be clear that all questions apply to RWA MIP6 applications.
